Title: Activation of kainate receptor GluK2–Neto2 complex
Description:
Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain
            the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in
            Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles
            and JavaScript.

Advertisement


Nature Structural & Molecular Biology

                         (2025)Cite this article


Kainate receptors (KARs) are tetrameric, ligand-gated ion channels of the ionotropic glutamate receptor family that mediate excitatory neurotransmission and modulate neuronal circuits and synaptic plasticity during development of the central nervous system. KARs are implicated in psychiatric and neurological diseases and represent a target of therapeutic intervention. Native KARs form complexes with neuropilin and tolloid-like auxiliary subunits (Neto1 and Neto2), which modulate their function, trafficking and synaptic localization. Here we present structures of rat GluK2 KAR in the apo closed state and in the open states activated by agonist kainate and positive allosteric modulator BPAM344, solved in the presence and absence of Neto2 using time-resolved cryo-electron microscopy. While the binding of Neto2 does not change the behavior of individual or dimeric ligand-binding domains (LBDs) or the ion channel, it prevents tightening of the interface between two LBD dimers during activation and slows the kinetics of deactivation. Our structures illuminate the mechanism of KAR activation and its modulation by Neto2.

Fast excitatory synaptic transmission in the central nervous system (CNS) is mediated primarily by glutamate, a neurotransmitter released from presynaptic terminals to activate three major postsynaptic ionotropic glutamate receptor (iGluR) subtypes: α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid receptors (AMPARs), N-methyl-d-aspartate receptors (NMDARs) and kainate receptors (KARs)1,2,3,4,5,6. Presynaptic KARs modulate neurotransmitter release at both excitatory and inhibitory synapses and tune neuronal excitability7,8. KARs are implicated in excitotoxicity and stroke, as well as neurological and psychiatric diseases9,10,11,12,13,14,15,16,17.

Functional KARs are tetrameric, cation-selective ion channels assembled from five different subunits, GluK1–GluK5 (refs. 1,5,18). The subunits GluK1–GluK3 exhibit low affinity to glutamate and can form homomeric channels, whereas GluK4 and GluK5 are characterized by higher affinity to glutamate and require the low-affinity subunits to coassemble into functional heteromeric channels19,20,21. The overwhelming majority of KARs in the CNS form macromolecular complexes with two auxiliary subunits, neuropilin- and tolloid-like proteins7,22,23,24,25,26 Neto1 and Neto2. These auxiliary subunits share the same type I transmembrane protein domain architecture, including extracellular C1r/C1s–Uegf–bone morphogenic protein domains, CUB1 and CUB2, a low-density lipoprotein class A domain, LDLa, and a single-pass transmembrane domain (TMD). Neto1 and Neto2 slow the deactivation and desensitization kinetics of KARs, accelerate their recovery from desensitization and increase the channel open probability7,27.

A molecular view of the GluK2–Neto2 assembly was provided by structures of the corresponding complex in the competitive antagonist-bound and agonist-bound nonconducting states28. While these structures uncovered the stoichiometry and approximate arrangement of domains in the GluK2–Neto2 complex, the structural basis of its activation has remained elusive. Recently, we explored the mechanism of KAR activation by solving the open-state structure of homomeric GluK2 in the presence of agonist glutamate and positive allosteric modulators (PAMs), lectin concanavalin A (ConA) and small molecule BPAM344 (BPAM), which worked synergistically to slow receptor desensitization29. As ConA and Neto2 bind to overlapping sites28,29, we endeavored to investigate alternative conditions to capture the open state of GluK2 in the absence of ConA. Surprisingly, we observed that the high-affinity KAR agonist kainic acid (KA) remarkably slows the kinetics of desensitization for GluK2 KARs in the presence of BPAM, facilitating the capture of open-state structures of GluK2 in the presence and absence of Neto2. We also determined the structures of GluK2 and the GluK2–Neto2 complex in the apo closed state. A comparison of the open-state and apo closed-state structures of GluK2 provides insight into the mechanisms underlying KAR activation and deactivation, as well as modulation of these gating functions by the auxiliary subunit Neto2.

We monitored GluK2 function using patch-clamp current recordings at −60 mV membrane potential from HEK 293F cells expressing rat GluK2. Prolonged application of 3 mM glutamate elicited a rapidly activating inward current that decayed quickly (time constant, τdes = 3.89 ± 0.27 ms, n = 10) to nearly zero value (current reduction after 3-s glutamate exposure, I3s/Imax = 0.0022 ± 0.0011, n = 10) because of receptor desensitization29 (Fig. 1a, left trace). Strikingly, desensitization became 270 times slower in the presence of 50 μM BPAM (τdes = 1.05 ± 0.13 s, n = 10). Nevertheless, 3 s after the beginning of glutamate application, the current amplitude became substantially reduced compared to its maximal value (I3s/Imax = 0.074 ± 0.021, n = 10)29 (Fig. 1a, right trace).

a,b, Whole-cell patch-clamp currents recorded at −60 mV membrane potential from HEK 293F cells expressing rat GluK2 in response to 1-s application of 3 mM glutamate (a) or 100 μM KA (b) alone (left traces) or in the continuous presence of 50 µM BPAM (right traces). The green arrow indicates a 3-s mark since the beginning of KA application. c,d, Cryo-EM reconstructions of GluK2 in the apo condition viewed parallel to the membrane (c) and their LBD layers viewed extracellularly (d), with protein subunits colored orange and light blue, lipids in purple and carbohydrates in light green. The red arrow illustrates rotation of the subunit B LBD in GluK2Apo-asym compared to GluK2Apo-2fold. e,f, Time-resolved cryo-EM reconstruction of GluK2 captured within 3 s of KA application in the continuous presence of BPAM viewed parallel to membrane (e) and its LBD layer viewed extracellularly (f). The density for KA is colored pink.

As an alternative to glutamate, we tested the agonist KA, which has higher potency and is, therefore, expected to exhibit slower kinetics2,27,30,31,32,33. Prolonged application of 100 μM KA alone elicited currents with a smaller amplitude and slightly slower decay (τdes = 5.00 ± 0.49 ms, n = 11) when compared to glutamate (Fig. 1b, left trace). However, a striking slowdown of desensitization was observed in the presence of 50 µM BPAM (τ = 8.96 ± 0.47 s, n = 5), retaining the substantially high current amplitude even after 3-s exposure to KA (I3s/Imax = 0.79 ± 0.04, n = 6) (Fig. 1b, right trace). On the basis of the dramatic deceleration of desensitization kinetics, we hypothesized that more than 80% of GluK2 receptors remained in the open state within 3 s of KA application in the continuous presence of BPAM.

For our structural experiments, we first purified GluK2 in the apo condition. To exclude possible traces of endogenous glutamate during purification, we supplemented the purified protein with 500 μM BPAM and subjected it to an additional step of size-exclusion chromatography (SEC) in the absence of ligands. We hypothesized that BPAM would stabilize the LBD clamshells in the fully open conformation, specifically the agonist-free state, as previously revealed by the GluK2BPAM structure34, and that BPAM itself would dissociate from the receptor during the SEC step. Indeed, our cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) experiments resolved GluK2 in the BPAM-free apo state. During cryo-EM data processing, we observed two distinct particle populations (Fig. 1c,d and Extended Data Fig. 1).

The first subset of particles yielded a two-fold symmetrical 3D reconstruction, GluK2Apo-2fold, with LBD densities demonstrating fully open clamshells without agonist bound. Moreover, the BPAM-binding pockets showed no BPAM density, confirming that GluK2Apo-2fold represents a true apo state. The second subset of particles yielded an asymmetric structure, GluK2Apo-asym, where one of two LBD dimers appeared to fall apart (Fig. 1d), similar to previously published KAR structures35,36,37,38,39. Interestingly, the LBD clamshells in the intact A/D dimer and subunit C are fully open, while that in subunit B is completely closed. Although no apparent agonist density inside the LBD of subunit B has been resolved, we cannot exclude the possibility of trace amounts of glutamate causing the clamshell closure and broken, asymmetrical conformation. Thus, only the GluK2Apo-2fold structure is further used as an apo state reference.

To elucidate the mechanism of GluK2 activation, we used an in-house time-resolved cryo-EM device, a solenoid-driven plunger40,41, which we built previously to solve the open-state structure of GluK2 in the presence of ConA29. This plunger allowed freezing of the GluK2 protein sample in the presence of BPAM within 2–3 s of applying KA. Cryo-EM data collected from this sample showed that the majority of particles were in the open state (Fig. 1e,f and Extended Data Fig. 2), consistent with our functional data (Fig. 1b). The corresponding 3D reconstruction, GluK2KA-BPAM, revealed densities for KA in the LBD clamshells and BPAM at the LBD dimer interfaces (Fig. 1e and Extended Data Fig. 3a,b). Importantly, GluK2KA-BPAM shows two-fold rotational symmetry and a dimer-of-dimers arrangement of LBDs (Fig. 1f), similar to the previously solved open-state structure of GluK2Glu-ConA-BPAM bound to glutamate, ConA and BPAM29.

Using the high-resolution 3D reconstructions as a guide, we built structural models of GluK2Apo-2fold and GluK2KA-BPAM (Fig. 2a,b). Similar to AMPARs42,43,44, the GluK2Apo-2fold and GluK2KA-BPAM structures showed the amino-terminal domain (ATD) and LBD layers assembled as dimers of dimers, where A/B and C/D dimers of the ATD and A/D and B/C dimers of the LBD are arranged symmetrically around the overall two-fold symmetry axis, with domain swapping between layers. The ATD and LBD dimers have individual local two-fold symmetry axes that do not coincide with each other or the overall two-fold symmetry axis. The ATD and LBD layers in GluK2Apo-2fold and GluK2KA-BPAM are slightly less separated (72.8 Å and 70.5 Å, respectively) compared to GluK2Glu-ConA-BPAM (74.5 Å)29 but are considerably farther away from each other compared to closed-state GluK2BPAM (61.3 Å)34 and putative desensitized-state structures (59 Å)29,35. The TMDs from four individual subunits, each containing three transmembrane helices (M1, M3 and M4) and a re-entrant loop M2 between M1 and M3, assemble into a pseudo-four-fold symmetrical ion channel, apparently closed in GluK2Apo-2fold (Fig. 2c) and open in GluK2KA-BPAM (Fig. 2d). In addition, three sets of linkers (S1–M1, M3–S2 and S2–M4) connect the TMDs to LBDs, the latter built of two polypeptide stretches, S1 and S2.

a,b, Closed GluK2Apo-2fold (a) and open GluK2KA-BPAM (b) structures viewed parallel to the membrane, with subunits A and C colored orange and subunits B and D colored light blue. Molecules of KA (green) and BPAM (dark blue) are shown as space-filling models. Carbohydrates (light green) and lipids (purple) are shown as sticks. The axes of the two-fold overall symmetry and local symmetry of the ATD and LBD dimers are shown as thin dashed and solid black lines, respectively. Thick black lines connect the ATD, LBD and Q/R site centers of mass (COM) (black spheres) and the distances between them are indicated. Cα atoms of S670 and P773 are shown as spheres of blue (GluK2Apo-2fold) and pink (GluK2KA-BPAM) color. c,d, Extracellular views of TMD layer in GluK2Apo-2fold (c) and open GluK2KA-BPAM (d), with secondary-structure elements labeled and residues contributing to the gate shown as sticks. Surface representation highlights the open pore in GluK2KA-BPAM versus the closed pore in GluK2Apo-2fold. e,f, LBD of subunit A in GluK2Apo-2fold (e) and GluK2KA-BPAM (f). A 19.6° rotation of lobe D2 toward D1 in GluK2KA-BPAM upon KA binding is illustrated by the pink arrow. g,h, LBD dimers in GluK2Apo-2fold (g) and GluK2KA-BPAM (h). Distances between Cα atoms of S670 and P773 are indicated. i,j, LBD tetramers in GluK2Apo-2fold (i) and GluK2KA-BPAM (j) viewed intracellularly, with the Cα atoms of S670 connected and pink arrows illustrating expansion forces applied to the M3–S2 linkers that induce channel opening.

Channel opening in GluK2KA-BPAM is triggered by KA binding to the clamshells of individual LBDs, which are empty and completely open in GluK2Apo-2fold (Fig. 2e,f). Upon KA binding, the GluK2KA-BPAM LBD clamshells undergo closure, with the lower lobe D2 rotating toward the upper lobe D1 by 19.6° in subunits A and C and 18.4° in subunits B and D. In back-to-back LBD dimers, which maintain their two-fold rotational symmetry and intact D1–D1 interfaces in both GluK2Apo-2fold and GluK2KA-BPAM, the individual LBD closures result in a notable separation of D2 lobes, illustrated by the increased distance between Cα atoms of S670 from 18 Å in GluK2Apo-2fold to 29 Å in GluK2KA-BPAM (Fig. 2g,h). In turn, this separation of D2 lobes in individual LBD dimers results in an expansion of the LBD layer (Fig. 2i,j). A similar expansion of the LBD tetramer was previously shown to trigger channel opening in KARs in the presence of ConA29, AMPARs45,46,47,48 and NMDARs49, highlighting it as a common feature of iGluR activation.

The ability of Neto2 to slow desensitization and deactivation of KARs has been previously characterized using glutamate as an agonist7,26,27. In this study, we investigated whether Neto2 produces similar effects on GluK2 kinetics when KA is used instead of glutamate. We observed that the rapidly activating inward current elicited by prolonged application of 100 μM KA at −60 mV membrane potential from HEK 293F cells expressing GluK2 alone quickly decayed back to nearly zero because of receptor desensitization (Fig. 3a, left). The desensitization decay followed a single exponential time course with the time constant, τdes = 5.00 ± 0.49 ms (n = 11). When Neto2 was coexpressed with GluK2, the desensitization decay became slower and was better described by a sum of two exponential functions, with τdes-fast = 13.6 ± 0.9 ms and τdes-slow = 182 ± 15 ms, and the fraction of the slow component, Ades-slow = 0.064 ± 0.022 (n = 10). This behavior was similar to that observed in experiments with glutamate7,27. Likewise, for comparison, we calculated the value of weighted τdes (24.5 ± 4.7 ms, n = 10), which was fivefold higher than the value of τdes calculated in the absence of Neto2 (Fig. 3a, right).

a–d, Whole-cell patch-clamp currents recorded at −60 mV membrane potential from HEK 293F cells expressing GluK2 alone (black traces) or GluK2 and Neto2 (red traces) in response to 10-s (a,c) or 2-ms (b,d) application of 100 μM KA alone (a,b) or in the continuous presence of 50 µM BPAM (c,d). Right: weighted time constants of desensitization (a,c) and deactivation (b,d) are shown as bar graphs. Asterisks indicate statistically significant differences (two-sided two-sample t-test; significant if P < 0.05). Biological replicates: n = 11 for GluK2 τdes in the absence of BPAM, n = 10 for GluK2–Neto2 τdes in the absence of BPAM, n = 11 for GluK2 τdeact in the absence of BPAM, n = 10 for GluK2–Neto2 τdeact in the absence of BPAM, n = 5 for GluK2 τdes in the presence of BPAM, n = 6 for GluK2–Neto2 τdes in the presence of BPAM, n = 6 for GluK2 τdeact in the presence of BPAM and n = 6 for GluK2–Neto2 τdeact in the presence of BPAM. Probabilities for the two-sided two-sample t-test: P = 0.0025 for GluK2 versus GluK2–Neto2 τdes in the absence of BPAM, P = 0.0015 for GluK2 versus GluK2–Neto2 τdeact in the absence of BPAM, P = 0.717 for GluK2 versus GluK2–Neto2 τdes in the presence of BPAM and P = 0.026 for GluK2 versus GluK2–Neto2 τdeact in the presence of BPAM. Data are the mean ± s.e.m. e,f, Cryo-EM reconstructions of GluK2–Neto2 in the apo condition (e) or in the presence of KA and BPAM (f) viewed parallel to membrane (top) and their LBD layers viewed extracellularly (bottom), with protein subunits colored orange and light blue, lipids in purple, carbohydrates in light green and Neto2 in red. Density for KA is colored pink. The red arrow in e illustrates rotation of the subunit B LBD in GluK2–0×Neto2Apo compared to GluK2–1×Neto2Apo.

Source data

Similarly, a strong slowdown of deactivation was observed in response to the short (2-ms) application of 100 μM KA in the presence of Neto2 (weighted τdeact = 14.2 ± 2.3 ms, n = 10) when compared to its absence (4.11 ± 0.59 ms, n = 11). In the presence of BPAM, both desensitization and deactivation kinetics were drastically slower. While the desensitization rate was not significantly different in the presence (9.57 ± 1.53 s, n = 6) versus absence (8.96 ± 0.47 s, n = 5) of Neto2, deactivation in the presence of Neto2 was significantly slower (weighted τdeact = 185 ± 25 ms, n = 6) than in its absence (108 ± 10 ms, n = 6).

To uncover the structural basis of GluK2 regulation by Neto2, we coexpressed GluK2 and Neto2 in HEK 293S cells and subjected the purified protein to cryo-EM. In the absence of ligands, we identified three distinct populations of particles representing the apo closed states with zero (GluK2–0×Neto2Apo), one (GluK2–1×Neto2Apo) or two (GluK2–2×Neto2Apo) molecules of Neto2 bound to the GluK2 tetramer (Fig. 3e and Extended Data Fig. 4). Interestingly, one LBD dimer in the GluK2–0×Neto2Apo structure was intact, while the other one fell apart, like that of GluK2Apo-asym (Fig. 1c,d). Unlike GluK2Apo-asym, however, the LBD clamshell in GluK2–0×Neto2Apo subunit B remains open, without any density for bound agonist, as observed in the other three subunits, confirming the true apo state of this structure. Importantly, the LBD layers in GluK2–1×Neto2Apo and GluK2–2×Neto2Apo show the dimer-of-dimers LBD arrangements, similar to the two-fold symmetrical apo structure, GluK2Apo-2fold, solved in the absence of Neto2 (Fig. 1c,d).

To resolve the open-state structures of the GluK2–Neto2 complex, we used time-resolved cryo-EM to prepare grids of the purified protein after exposure to KA for less than 3 s in the continuous presence of BPAM. During cryo-EM data processing, we identified three distinct populations of particles that yielded 3D reconstructions of GluK2 tetramer with zero (GluK2–0×Neto2KA-BPAM), one (GluK2–1×Neto2KA-BPAM), or two (GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM) Neto2 molecules bound (Fig. 3f and Extended Data Figs. 5 and 6). The resulting GluK2–0×Neto2KA-BPAM structure was nearly identical to GluK2KA-BPAM (Extended Data Fig. 7). GluK2–1×Neto2KA-BPAM and GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM were characterized by a dimer-of-dimers LBD arrangement and the same approximate location of one or two bound Neto2 molecules like the Neto2-bound structures obtained in the apo condition (Fig. 3e).

Neto2-bound structures determined in the absence of ligands (GluK2–1×Neto2Apo and GluK2–2×Neto2Apo) and in the presence of KA and BPAM (GluK2–1×Neto2KA-BPAM and GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM) reveal the GluK2–Neto2 contact interfaces at improved resolution compared to the previous structures of GluK2–Neto2 in the competitive antagonist-bound and putative desensitized states28. The four major structural domains of Neto2, CUB1, CUB2, LDLa and the C-terminal TMD (Fig. 4a,b), follow each other along the surface of the receptor in the extracellular to intracellular direction. The improved resolution of our structures allows visualization of previously unresolved flexible linkers connecting CUB1 to CUB2 (residues 160–176) and LDLa to the TMD (residues 333–338), the C terminus (residues 377–383), which interacts with the M1–M2 loop of GluK2, and glycosylation of Neto2 at N311. Our structures also reveal the unique interfaces that the four major structural domains of Neto2 make with all three structured GluK2 domain layers.

a,b, Broad (a) and narrow (b) faces of the GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM structure viewed parallel to the membrane (gray stripe), with subunits A and C colored orange, subunits B and D colored light blue and Neto2 colored red. Molecules of KA (green) and BPAM (dark blue) are shown as space-filling models. Carbohydrates (light green) and lipids (purple) are shown as sticks. The axes of the two-fold overall symmetry and local symmetry of the ATD and LBD dimers are shown as thin dashed and solid black lines, respectively. Thick black lines connect the ATD, LBD and Q/R site centers of mass (black spheres) and the distances between them are indicated. Boxed regions are expanded in c–f. c–f, Close-up views of the GluK2–Neto2 contact interfaces between the lower lobe of GluK2 subunit A(C) ATD and CUB1 domain of Neto2 (c), loop 1 of GluK2 subunit B(D) LBD and CUB2 domain of Neto2 (d), lower lobe of GluK2 subunit A(C) LBD and Neto2 domains CUB2 and LDLa (e) and M1 and M1–M2 loop of GluK2 TMD and α1, TM1 and C terminus of Neto2 (f).

The extracellular region of Neto2 makes extensive contacts with the ATD and LBD layers of the receptor. The CUB1 domain shares a 316-Å2 interface with the ATD of GluK2 subunits A and C, mediated mainly by electrostatic interactions between K216, K219, and R220 of the GluK2 ATD and E95, D144, E145 and E146 of CUB1 (Fig. 4c). Confirming the importance of these interactions, regulation of GluK2 function by Neto2 was largely impaired by D144A, E145A, E146A and E148A substitutions in the CUB1 domain50 or abolished by the K216A and R220A substitutions in the GluK2 ATD28. The CUB2 domain contacts loop 1 in the upper lobe of the GluK2 subunit B and D LBDs, sharing a 355-Å2 GluK2–Neto2 interface involving polar and hydrophobic interactions between K448, S449, D450, K451, P452 and L453 of GluK2 and N232, S257, T258, V259 and N261 of CUB2 (Fig. 4d). Confirming the importance of the second interface for Neto2 function, the K448A, D450A and K451A substitutions in GluK2 accelerated desensitization of the GluK2–Neto2 complex28. However, the membrane-facing side of the CUB2 domain, mainly involving Y220, together with the LDLa domain of Neto2, forms the third, 357-Å2 GluK2–Neto2 interface, which connects Neto2 to the lower lobe of the GluK2 LBD belonging to the second LBD dimer (Fig. 4e). Therefore, the CUB2 and LDLa domains of Neto2 cross-interact with protomers of two different LBD dimers and are, thus, poised to regulate their relative positioning during gating. Necessity of the LDLa domain for modulation of KAR activity by Neto2 was demonstrated by a dramatic reduction in GluK2-mediated current amplitude in response to the substitution of two cysteines in LDLa to serine residues7.

The fourth GluK2–Neto2 interface has the largest surface area (1,022 Å2) and mostly involves hydrophobic interactions between TMDs. On the Neto2 side, it is contributed by (1) helix α1, a short region that precedes the transmembrane helix TM1 and runs nearly parallel to the membrane along its extracellular side; (2) TM1 itself; and (3) the C terminus, which follows TM1 (Fig. 4f). On the GluK2 side, the fourth interface involves the transmembrane helix M1, which contacts α1 and TM1 of Neto2, as well as the M1–M2 loop, which forms the GluK2 bottom cap and intracellular portals and mainly contacts the C terminus of Neto2 (Fig. 4f). Highlighting the importance of the M1–M2 loop for Neto2 function, its replacement with the M1–M2 loop of the AMPAR subunit GluA2 accelerated desensitization of the GluK2–Neto2 complex28.

To reveal structural changes responsible for modulation of GluK2 function by Neto2 (Fig. 3a–d), we first compared the ion channel pore in GluK2–2×Neto2Apo (Fig. 5a) and GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM (Fig. 5b). Typical for the closed-pore conformations, the gate region in GluK2–2×Neto2Apo is narrow, with the side chains of T652, A656, T660 and M664 forming a hydrophobic constriction, very similar to that in GluK2BPAM (Extended Data Fig. 8a) and, therefore, impermeable to both water and ions29. In contrast, the gate region of the GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM pore becomes much wider, with kinking of the pore-lining M3 helices at the gating hinge in all four GluK2 subunits, a representative structural change accompanying channel pore opening in the ConA-bound GluK2KA-ConA-BPAM structure29 (Extended Data Fig. 8b). Measurements of the pore radius in GluK2–2×Neto2Apo, as well as in all apo structures, showed that it is nearly identical to that in GluK2BPAM (Fig. 5c), indicating that all apo structures are indeed in the closed conformation and are impermeable to water and ions29. On the other hand, the pore geometry in GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM, as well as in all other structures solved in the presence of KA and BPAM, was nearly identical to the pore geometry in GluK2KA-ConA-BPAM (Fig. 5c and Extended Data Fig. 8b), suggesting that all these structures represent open states, with their pores permeable to water and ions29.

a,b, Pore-forming segments M2 and M3 in GluK2–2×Neto2Apo (a) and GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM (b), with residues lining the pore shown as sticks. Only two (B and D) of four subunits are shown, with the front and back subunits (A and C) omitted for clarity. The pore profiles are shown as space-filling models (gray). The red arrow indicates the gating hinge where M3 bends during channel opening. c, Pore radius for GluK2Apo-2fold (blue), GluK2Apo-asym (cyan), GluK2–0×Neto2Apo (chartreuse), GluK2–1×Neto2Apo (dark blue), GluK2–2×Neto2Apo (green), GluK2BPAM (dark purple; PDB 8FWS), GluK2KA-BPAM (red), GluK2–0×Neto2KA-BPAM (light orange), GluK2–1×Neto2KA-BPAM (dark orange), GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM (purple) and GluK2Glu-ConA-BPAM (pink; PDB 9B36) calculated using HOLE. The vertical dashed line denotes the radius of a water molecule, 1.4 Å.

We next compared the LBD layers in GluK2–2×Neto2Apo and GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM structures (Fig. 6). We observed that LBD clamshells in GluK2–2×Neto2Apo are fully open, similar to GluK2Apo-2fold, without any signs of agonist bound. However, the LBD clamshells in GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM undergo closure exemplified by rotation of the D2 lobe toward D1 (Fig. 6a). Interestingly, the extent of the clamshell closure in GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM (20.6° D2 rotation in subunits A and C and 20.7° in subunits B and D; Fig. 6a,b) is slightly larger than that in GluK2KA-BPAM (19.6° D2 rotation in subunits A and C and 18.4° in subunits B and D; Fig. 6c,d). Nevertheless, the dramatic separation of the D2 lobes upon the individual LBD clamshell closures in GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM (signified by the increase in distance between Cα atoms of S670 from 19 Å in GluK2–2×Neto2Apo to 29 Å in GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM; Fig. 6b) is nearly identical to that observed in the absence of Neto2 (18 Å in GluK2Apo-2fold versus 29 Å in GluK2KA-BPAM; Fig. 6d). The slightly enhanced closure of the individual LBD clamshells in the presence of Neto2, therefore, compensates for the loosening of the D1–D1 interface during activation, which happens in the absence (the distance between Cα atoms of P773 increases from 13 Å in GluK2Apo-2fold to 15 Å in GluK2KA-BPAM; Fig. 6d) but not in the presence of Neto2 (the distance between Cα atoms of P773 remains 15 Å in GluK2–2×Neto2Apo and GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM; Fig. 6b).

Cα atoms of S670 and P773 are shown as spheres. b, Superposition of LBD dimers from GluK2–2×Neto2Apo and GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM. Distances between Cα atoms of S670 and P773 are indicated. c, Upper lobe D1-based superposition of subunit A LBD monomers from GluK2Apo-2fold (cyan) and GluK2KA-BPAM (pink). The surface area of the contact interface between two LBD dimers is indicated.

While the individual LBD clamshells, LBD dimers and ion channel pores in Neto2-bound structures appear to behave in the same way as in the absence of Neto2, the relative positioning of the LBD dimers with respect to each other appears to be dramatically different. Indeed, in the presence of Neto2, the interaction of two LBD dimers upon GluK2 activation becomes less pronounced, as characterized by the reduced surface area of the dimer–dimer interface in GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM (129 Å2) compared to GluK2–2×Neto2Apo (139 Å2) (Fig. 6f,g and Supplementary Video 1). In contrast, channel opening in the absence of Neto2 is accompanied by substantial strengthening of the interaction between two GluK2 LBD dimers, as evidenced by a fourfold increased interdimer interface in GluK2KA-BPAM (852 Å2) compared to GluK2Apo-2fold (219 Å2) (Fig. 6h–i and Supplementary Video 1).

In this study, we present the apo structures of the KAR GluK2 in the absence and presence of the auxiliary subunit Neto2. The apo structures of GluK2 with (GluK2–2×Neto2Apo) and without (GluK2Apo-2fold) Neto2 are very similar, characterized by fully open LBD clamshells without any signs of bound agonist. Further, the dimer-of-dimers arrangement of the LBD layer with intact D1–D1 interfaces in individual dimers and closed ion channel pores suggest that we solved the true apo state of GluK2 (Figs. 2, 5 and 6). These features of the apo GluK2 structures are grossly similar to the apo51 and competitive antagonist-bound42 AMPAR, or BPAM-bound KAR34,52 structures. Interestingly, a recently reported apo structure of GluK2 had different features, including closed LBD clamshells and a fourfold symmetrical LBD layer, where both LBD dimers dissociated into individual monomers39, similar to the putative desensitized-state structure35. One possible explanation for this structural disparity is the presence of residual glutamate in the protein preparation for the previously published structure, sufficient to transform the channel into the putative desensitized state.

We also successfully captured open-state GluK2 structures in near-physiological conditions. By using the high-affinity agonist KA together with the PAM BPAM, we were able to slow the desensitization kinetics of GluK2. Subsequently, we used time-resolved cryo-EM to trap most channels in the open state before they could transition to the desensitized state. We found that the dramatic slowdown of desensitization kinetics in the presence of KA and BPAM (Fig. 1b) correlates with tightening of the dimer–dimer interface in GluK2KA-BPAM compared to GluK2Apo-2fold (Fig. 6g,h). Such a correlation is consistent with the vision of desensitization as a KAR gating process that occurs in two steps: shallow desensitization associated with rupture of the LBD dimer interfaces29,53 and deep desensitization linked to the dissociation of LBD dimers29,35,53. Indeed, the second step, which is missing in closely related AMPARs46,54,55,56 and determines the slow component of KAR desensitization, assumes complete breakage of the LBD dimer–dimer interface. Accordingly, tightening of this interface should slow or prevent deep desensitization of KARs. Because the binding sites for Neto2 and ConA overlap, the identified condition of joint KA and BPAM application allowed us to solve the open-state structure of GluK2 not only in the absence of ConA but also in the presence of Neto2.

Previously, ConA was suggested to act as a spacer between the ATD and LBD layers in GluK2KA-ConA-BPAM structures29, increasing their separation when compared to GluK2BPAM34 and desensitized-state structures29,35,38. However, it turns out that the GluK2KA-ConA-BPAM structure is only 3 Å taller than GluK2Apo-2fold and GluK2KA-BPAM (Fig. 7a). Even the GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM structure, which is 4 Å shorter than GluK2Apo-2fold and GluK2KA-BPAM, is taller than GluK2BPAM and the desensitized-state structures. Thus, the separation of the ATD and LBD layers does not appear to be a requisite for the open state. On the other hand, all apo and open-state structures show much stronger separation of these layers than in GluK2BPAM or the desensitized-state structures, suggesting that their separation might be important for the process of activation. Interestingly, depending on the presence of a combination of PAMs or the auxiliary subunit Neto2, the activation process can be accompanied by different rotations of the ATD layer (Fig. 7a). While such rotation might be relevant to the interaction of KARs with presynaptic or transsynaptic proteins, it does not appear to be relevant to the conformations of individual LBDs, LBD dimers or the ion channel pore in the open state. On the other hand, the distance between the ATD layer and the LBDs, as well as its relative rotation, depends on bound ligand, which in turn can affect KAR gating kinetics by altering the relative positioning or dynamics of the main structural domains. Therefore, Neto2 binding eliminates the substantial tightening of the LBD dimer–dimer interface, which occurs in its absence (Fig. 6f,h). We propose that the loss of interdimer contacts because of restraints put on the receptor by Neto2 slows the open-to-closed state transition and results in deceleration of deactivation and desensitization kinetics (Figs. 3a,b,d and 7b,c). Further insights into the molecular mechanism by which the auxiliary subunit Neto2 regulates KAR function will emerge once KAR structures are solved in the preactive state, an intermediate or transitional state among the closed, open and desensitized57.

a, Shown are structures of closed GluK2Apo-2fold and open GluK2KA-BPAM, GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM, and GluK2Glu-ConA-BPAM (PDB 9B36) aligned based on the ion channel and viewed parallel to membrane (top) and extracellularly (bottom), with subunits A and C colored orange, subunits B and D colored light blue, Neto2 colored red and ConA colored green. Black lines connect the ATD and Q/R site centers of mass, with the distances between them indicated (top). Movement of the ATD layer upon channel opening is illustrated by blue arrows, with the rotation angle indicated (bottom). b,c, Cartoons illustrating the closed-to-open transition of KAR in the absence (b) and presence (c) of Neto2. Neto2 prevents tightening of the LBD dimer–dimer interface during channel opening and decelerates receptor deactivation.

DNA for the full-length rat GluK2 (GenBank CAA77778.1), with V at position 567, C at position 571 and Q at position 621 (the Q/R site), was amplified using PCR and inserted into the pEG BacMam vector with a thrombin cleavage site, eGFP and streptavidin affinity tag at the C terminus. Similarly, DNA for rat Neto2 (GenBank ACS44815.1) was cloned into the pEG BacMam vector with a thrombin cleavage site, mCherry and 8×His affinity tag at the C terminus. The bacmid and baculoviruses were produced in Sf9 cells (Gibco, 12659017) cultured in Sf-900 III SFM medium (Gibco) at 27 °C using standard methods. The recombinant complex of GluK2–Neto2 was expressed in HEK 293S cells (American Type Culture Collection (ATCC), CRL-3022) cultured in Freestyle 293 expression medium (Gibco) at 30 °C and 6% CO2. For patch-clamp experiments, HEK 293F cells (ATCC, CRL-1573) were maintained at 37 °C and 6% CO2 in DMEM, supplemented with 10% FBS.

Purification of recombinant complex GluK2–Neto2 was carried out as described previously for GluK2 alone, with slight modifications29. In brief, P2 viruses of GluK2 and Neto2 were made separately and stored as 20× stocks. The virus stocks at the ratio of 4:1 (GluK2 to Neto2) were added to HEK 293S cells at a density of ~3.0 × 106 cells per ml and incubated at 37 °C and 6% CO2. The cell culture was induced by 10 mM sodium butyrate at 12–15 h after transduction and the temperature was changed to 30 °C. The cells were harvested at 72 h after transduction by low-speed centrifugation (5,500g, 10 min), followed by a wash with 1× PBS pH 7.4 and another centrifugation (5,500g, 15 min). The cell pellet from 2 L of culture was resuspended in 100 ml of ice-cold lysis buffer composed of 20 mM HEPES pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 0.8 μM aprotinin, 2 μg ml−1 leupeptin, 2 μM pepstatin A and 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. The cells were lysed by sonication for 3 min (three cycles of 15 s on and 15 s off). The cell lysate was centrifuged (5,500g, 15 min) to remove cell debris and the supernatant was subjected to ultracentrifugation (186,000g, 1 h) to isolate cell membranes. The cell membranes were mechanically homogenized and solubilized for 2 h in a buffer containing 20 mM HEPES pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 1% digitonin (Cayman Chemical Company, 14952) and the protease inhibitors mentioned above. The insoluble material was removed using ultracentrifugation (186,000g, 1 h). The supernatant was mixed with pre-equilibrated streptavidin-linked resin (2 ml) and rotated for 10–14 h at 4 °C. Subsequently, the protein-bound resin was washed with 30–35 ml of buffer containing 20 mM HEPES pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl and 0.05% digitonin. The protein was eluted in 12–15 ml of the same buffer supplemented with 2.5 mM d-desthiobiotin. The eluted protein was concentrated and subjected to thrombin digestion (1:200 w/w) at 22 °C for 90 min to remove eGFP, mCherry and affinity tags. The digest reaction was then injected into a Superose 6 10/300 GL SEC column (GE Healthcare) pre-equilibrated with a buffer containing 20 mM HEPES pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl and 0.05% digitonin. The peak fractions corresponding to tetrameric GluK2–Neto2 complex were pooled and concentrated to 5–6 mg ml−1.

To purify GluK2 and GluK2–Neto2 in the apo state, the concentrated protein was mixed with 500 μM BPAM344, incubated for 25–30 min on ice and injected again into the SEC column pre-equilibrated with a buffer containing 20 mM HEPES pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl and 0.05% digitonin. All procedures, unless otherwise specified, were carried out at 4 °C.

We used our in-house vitrification system developed for rapid grid preparation as described previously29. For cryo-EM grid preparation, we used UltrAuFoil R 1.2/1.3, 300-mesh gold grids (EMS). Before the sample application, the grids were treated in a PELCO easyGlow cleaning system (Ted Pella, 25 s, 15 mA) to render their surface hydrophilic. For the open state, purified GluK2–Neto2 or GluK2 protein at the concentration of 5–6 mg ml−1 was incubated with 500 µM BPAM344 for 20–30 min on ice. Subsequently, 1.5 µl of protein sample was applied to both sides of the grid and 0.5 µl of KA at 20 mM was applied to one side of the grid, blotted for 1.5 s from the other side and immediately vitrified in liquid ethane cooled by liquid nitrogen. The total time between KA application and plunge-freezing was shorter than 3 s. For the apo state, we prepared grids of GluK2–Neto2 and GluK2 using FEI Vitrobot Mark IV (Thermo Fisher Scientific) set at 4 °C and 100% humidity. For this, 3 µl of protein solution was applied to each grid, which was then vitrified using blot time of 3 s, wait time of 30 s and blot force of 2. The grids were imaged on Titan Krios transmission EM instruments (Thermo Fisher Scientific) operating at 300 kV, equipped with a postcolumn GIF Quantum energy filter (slit width set to 20 eV) and a Gatan K3 direct electron detection camera, using Leginon 3.5, Serial EM 4.0 or EPU 2.0 software. We collected 22,262 images for GluK2apo, 16,261 images for GluK2–Neto2apo, 5,677 images for GluK2KA-BPAM and 14,794 images for GluK2–Neto2KA-BPAM in the counting mode across the defocus range of −1.0 to −2.0 µm. The data collection details are given in Supplementary Table 1.

For all datasets, cryo-EM data processing followed a similar protocol. Briefly, the data processing was performed using cryoSPARC (version 4.4.1)58 (Extended Data Fig. 1). Video frames were aligned using patch motion correction. Contrast transfer function (CTF) estimation was performed using the patch CTF estimation. Following CTF estimation, micrographs were manually inspected and those with outliers in defocus values, ice thickness and astigmatism and micrographs with lower predicted CTF-correlated resolution were excluded from further processing (individually assessed for each parameter relative to the overall distribution). Initially, particles were picked using blob picker, followed by multiple rounds of two-dimensional (2D) classification to create templates for template picking and then Topaz training. After removal of duplicates, picked particles were extracted with binning. After several rounds of reference-free 2D classification and heterogenous classification, cleaned particles were extracted without binning. At this stage, the GluK2KA-BPAM dataset revealed only one population of particles, while the GluK2apo, GluK2–Neto2apo and GluK2–Neto2KA-BPAM datasets revealed multiple conformations. Correspondingly, particles in the last three datasets were classified into GluK2Apo-asym and GluK2Apo-2fold, GluK2–0×Neto2Apo, GluK2–1×Neto2Apo and GluK2–2×Neto2Apo and GluK2–0×Neto2KA-BPAM, GluK2–1×Neto2KA-BPAM and GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM and each subset was subjected to reference-based motion correction individually. To improve resolution, ATD and LBD–TMD were subjected to local refinement with a mask or particle subtraction followed by cleanup and nonuniform refinement. The processing of individual datasets is shown in Extended Data Figs. 1,2 and 5.

The models of GluK2Apo-asym, GluK2Apo-2fold and GluK2–0×Neto2Apo were built in Coot (version 0.9.8.1)59 using cryo-EM density and the GluK2BPAM structure (Protein Data Bank (PDB) 8FWQ) as a guide. The GluK2KA-BPAM and GluK2–0×Neto2KA-BPAM models were built in Coot using cryo-EM density and the GluK2Glu-ConA-BPAM structure (PDB 9B36) as a guide. The GluK2–1×Neto2Apo and GluK2–2×Neto2Apo models were built in Coot using cryo-EM density and GluK2Apo-2fold and GluK2–1×Neto2des (PDB 7F57) structures as guides. The GluK2–1×Neto2KA-BPAM and GluK2–2×Neto2KA-BPAM) models were built in Coot using cryo-EM density and the GluK2KA-BPAM and GluK2–2×Neto2Apo structures as guides. The resulting models were subjected to the real-space refinement in PHENIX (version 1.18)60 and visualized in Chimera (version 1.13.1)61 or Pymol (version 2.5.2, Schrödinger). Validation statistics for the models are summarized in Supplementary Table 1. Domain rotations were determined using DynDom 1.5 (http://dyndom.cmp.uea.ac.uk/dyndom/). The pore radius was calculated using HOLE (version 2.1)62.

DNA encoding GluK2 and Neto2 (described above) was introduced into a pIRES plasmid for expression in eukaryotic cells that were engineered to produce GFP through a downstream internal ribosome entry site. HEK 293F cells (ATCC, CRL-1573) grown on glass coverslips in 35-mm dishes were transiently transfected with 1–5 μg of plasmid DNA using Lipofectamine 2000 Reagent (Invitrogen). Recordings were made 24 to 48 h after transfection at room temperature. Currents from whole cells, typically held at −60 mV potential, were recorded using an Axopatch 200B amplifier (Molecular Devices), filtered at 5 kHz and digitized at 10 kHz using low-noise data acquisition system Digidata 1440A and pCLAMP 10.2 software (Molecular Devices). The external solution contained 150 mM NaCl, 2.4 mM KCl, 4 mM CaCl2, 4 mM MgCl2 and 10 mM HEPES pH 7.3; 7 mM NaCl was added to the extracellular activating solution containing 3 mM glutamate to improve visualization of the border between two solutions coming out of a two-barrel theta glass pipette, which allowed its more precise positional adjustment for faster solution exchange. The internal solution contained 150 mM CsF, 10 mM NaCl, 10 mM EGTA and 20 mM HEPES pH 7.3. Rapid solution exchange was achieved with a two-barrel theta glass pipette controlled by a piezoelectric translator. Typical 10–90% rise times were 200–300 µs, as measured from junction potentials at the open tip of the patch pipette after recordings. Data analysis was performed using the Clampfit 10.3 and Origin 2023 software (OriginLab).

Statistical analysis was performed using Origin 2023. Statistical significance was calculated using a two-sample t-test, with significance assumed if P < 0.05. In all figure legends, n represents the number of independent biological replicates. All quantitative data were presented as the mean ± s.e.m.

The atomic coordinates used for model building and structural comparisons were also obtained from the PDB under accession codes 5KUF, 7F57, 7F5A, 8F0O, 8FWQ, 8FWS and 9B36. Data and materials can be obtained from the corresponding author upon request. Source data are provided with this paper.

Title: Space weathering effects in Bennu asteroid samples
Description:
Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain
            the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in

            and JavaScript.

Advertisement


Nature Geoscience

                         (2025)Cite this article


The OSIRIS-REx mission deployed contact pad samplers to collect regolith from the uppermost surface of the asteroid Bennu that was exposed to the space environment. Space weathering processes, dominated by micrometeoroid impacts and solar irradiation, modify the mineralogy and chemistry of exposed surfaces to produce solar wind-amorphized layers on clays, metallic whiskers associated with high temperature melts and Fe nitride created by the reaction of indigenous N-bearing gases with space-weathered surfaces. Here, we use cosmogenic noble gases and radionuclides to suggest that the upper metre of Bennu's regolith has been exposed to cosmic rays for 2–7 million years, consistent with remote sensing observations indicating that the asteroid's surface is dynamic and regularly modified by mass movement. Solar energetic particle track and microcrater densities constrain the space weathering spectral changes observed in Hokioi crater to <50,000 years. These spectral changes are driven largely by the accumulation of impact melt deposits on particle surfaces, although compositional or grain size effects may also occur. Comparison of Bennu samples with those collected from the asteroids Ryugu and Itokawa suggest that micrometeoroid impacts might play a more active and rapid role in the space weathering of asteroidal surfaces than was initially suggested, particularly for carbonaceous bodies.

The NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Administration) Origins, Spectral Interpretation, Resource Identification, Security—Regolith Explorer (OSIRIS-REx) spacecraft returned centimetre-scale and smaller regolith particles from Hokioi crater on (101955) Bennu, a relatively rare, spectrally blue (B-type) carbonaceous asteroid1,2. The spacecraft's Touch-and-Go Sample Acquisition Mechanism (TAGSAM)3 captured the ‘bulk' ~122 g sample, which consists of mixed material from the surface and potentially from up to ~0.5 m in depth4. In addition, the TAGSAM included 24 contact pads consisting of stainless-steel Velcro, each ~17 mm in diameter and arranged symmetrically around the circumference of the TAGSAM base (Extended Data Fig. 1)3. Their purpose was to sample Bennu's uppermost regolith to explore the mineralogical, chemical and spectroscopic changes resulting from exposure to space weathering.

Spacecraft data provided our first insights into the extent of space weathering effects across Bennu's surface. Reflectance spectra showed that small craters on Bennu, especially Hokioi, are redder in the visible wavelengths than the global average; these craters were inferred to be the youngest on Bennu, with a surface exposure age estimated to be <105 years (ref. 2). Post-sampling observations of Hokioi crater confirmed that freshly exposed materials are spectrally redder and darker in the visible wavelengths than the more space weathered, spectrally blue material exposed across most of Bennu's surface2,4. However, spectra from an aliquot of the returned sample are even more red-sloped and darker than spectra collected by the spacecraft1, suggesting that, despite its inferred young exposure age, material at the surface of Hokoi crater has already undergone considerable space weathering.

Upon examination of the TAGSAM, we found that all contact pads contained adhering material, including particles captured in the Velcro loops, smaller particles in the base weave and dust particles coating much of the surface area (Extended Data Fig. 1) comprising ≪100 mg. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis shows that contact pad particles are mineralogically similar to the bulk sample1, including fine-grained phyllosilicates, magnetite framboids and plaquettes, Fe and Fe–Ni sulfides, carbonates, phosphates and many other minor and trace minerals5. SEM analyses also show that all four particles extracted thus far from contact pad OREX-452000-0, as well as tens of particles from the bulk sample, show evidence for space weathering on their surfaces, including vesicular impact melt deposits and micrometeoroid impact craters (<10 µm in diameter; Fig. 1 and Extended Data Table 1).

a, A SEM image of particle OREX-452001-0, with microcraters indicated by yellow squares. b,c, Typical microcraters (b) and melt deposits (c) on the surface of OREX-452001-0, indicated by red arrows.

The quenched impact melt deposits (hereafter ‘melts') are present on ~10–20% of the tens of particles analysed from the bulk sample to date and all four particles extracted from the contact pad. One contact pad particle (OREX-452001-0) exhibits ~180 individual melt deposits over ~0.6 mm2 (Fig. 1). The melts range in size and coverage, from splashes only a few micrometres wide to coatings covering >200 µm2 of the particle surface. We extracted focused ion beam (FIB) sections to investigate the microstructure and chemistry of space weathering features in the transmission electron microscope (TEM).

The bulk compositions of the melts (Supplementary Table 2) are approximately solar for most major elements (for example, Mg, Si and Fe), except S, which is depleted from the melts owing to its volatility, resulting in the formation of Fe metal grains in some melts. The melts also contain abundant nano- and micro-phase inclusions of Fe–Ni–S phases and can also include larger immiscible Fe–Ni–S melts, either as discrete deposits or as irregular swirls (schlieren) in the host silicate melts.

In addition to micro- and nano-phase inclusions, there are widespread vesicles throughout the melts (~500 nm in diameter) and also concentrated at the melt interface with the phyllosilicate-rich matrix (~50 nm in diameter). The large vesicles resemble those in melts produced by infra-red laser irradiation of hydrated carbonaceous chondrites—where the vesicles form from evolved volatiles (mainly H2O)6. This H2O probably contributes to the broadening of the 2.7-µm water feature observed in the spacecraft spectra7. The smaller vesicles resemble those observed in solar wind-irradiated surfaces of particles returned from Itokawa8 and laboratory experiments9,10.

In contrast to the silicate melts described above, the Fe–Ni–S melt deposits are crystalline and dominated by fine-grained mixtures of pyrrhotite, pentlandite, FeNi metal and minor magnetite. On one such melt deposit (OREX-501017-101), we observed a polycrystalline ~10-nm Fe nitride layer (Fig. 2) that consists of an intergrowth of siderazot (Fe3N1.3) and roaldite (Fe4N). The Fe nitride minerals probably formed through a gas-phase reaction of the Fe metal layer with a N-bearing volatile phase, most probably indigenous ammonia11. The discovery of nitrides in Ryugu12 and Bennu samples suggests an unexpected but possibly common process involving interactions between ammonia and the space-weathered regolith particles on carbonaceous asteroids.

a, A TEM image of a FIB section of particle OREX-501017-101, with the iron nitride layer indicated by yellow arrows. b, A higher-magnification image of the polycrystalline layer. c, The Fe–N–S (RGB) composite chemical map of the area shown in b. d,e, A high-resolution TEM image (e) showing that the Fe nitride is crystalline and a fast Fourier transform pattern (d) from the inset red box, consistent with the mineral roaldite.

A sulfide melt on particle OREX-803164-100 lacks an Fe nitride layer; however, on that deposit, we observe the formation of multiple FeNi-rich metal whiskers protruding up to ~100 nm from the surface (Fig. 3), like those observed on sulfides in samples from Itokawa13 and the Moon14 (see ‘Impact melt deposits' section in the Supplementary Data).

a, A SEM image of particle OREX-803164-0 containing a sulfide-rich melt droplet (labelled ‘S-rich melt'). The dashed yellow line indicates the boundary between the sulfide melt and the silicate melt. The green box indicates a magnified area shown in the subsequent panels. The red and yellow arrows indicate a Ni-poor whisker and a Ni-rich whisker, respectively. b, Yellow arrows point toward Ni-rich whiskers, more of which can be seen in this magnified view, and the red arrow points towards the Ni-poor whisker. c,d, Corresponding Ni (c) and S (d) maps showing that the whiskers are Ni-rich and S-depleted. Arrows pointing towards Ni-rich whiskers in d are coloured black for clarity.

Evidence for solar wind irradiation was identified in particles that exhibit other characteristics consistent with surface exposure on Bennu (for example, microcraters and melts). In addition, we examined areas immediately underlying melts superimposed on previously solar wind-exposed surfaces.

On particle OREX-501017-102, we observe a less porous, compact surface layer, ranging in thickness from 60 to 150 nm, consistent with the expected implantation depths for solar wind H+ and He+ in silicate materials estimated by Monte Carlo atomic collision modelling9,15. This compact layer exhibits heterogeneous crystallinity, with a predominantly amorphous surface transitioning to poorly crystalline, and ultimately long-range crystalline order at the base (Extended Data Fig. 2). The compact surface layer is also chemically processed, with a 10-nm-thick rim enriched in Mg and depleted in Si, overlying a similar layer depleted in Mg and enriched in Si. This chemical signature is commonly observed in other solar wind-irradiated returned samples and analogues9,10,16 (see ‘Solar wind irradiation' section in the Supplementary Data).

We directly measured solar wind-derived He in particles that showed evidence for surface exposure (OREX-501017-102 and OREX-501017-100). Electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) measurements revealed heterogeneously distributed He in the compact surface layer of particle OREX-501017-102 (Fig. 4). We also identified He in OREX-501017-100 in small vesicles concentrated at the melt–matrix interface. These observations support the inferred relationship between interface vesicles and the implantation of solar wind gases.

a,b, High-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) images of the OREX-501017-100 (a) and OREX-501017-102 (b) samples analysed with EELS, with measurement locations identified by coloured boxes. c,d, Interface between melt deposits and the underlying matrix in particle OREX-501017-100 from different regions where the EELS spectra were obtained, and shown in g. e, A HAADF image of the solar wind-irradiated rim in particle OREX-501017-102. f, A HAADF image of the matrix, below the implantation depth for solar wind, in particle OREX-501017-102 (not shown in a and b). SW, solar wind. g, EELS spectra (arbitrarily offset in intensity only for clarity) showing the presence of He, with spectrum colours corresponding to the boxes in c–f. The peak positions for the He K-edge shifts to higher energies (between 22 and 23 eV, as indicated by the dashed grey lines) with higher concentration detected36.

Olivine and pyroxene grains exposed to the space environment are rare in Bennu samples1,5. We extracted a FIB section from a forsterite grain on the surface of a contact pad particle (OREX-452001-0) and observed a nanocrystalline solar wind-damaged rim ~100 nm wide and solar energetic particle (SEP) tracks with a density of ~1.4 × 109 cm−2 (Fig. 5). The rim microstructure is similar to solar wind-damaged rims in olivine grains from Itokawa and the Moon with similar SEP track densities17.

a, A SEM image with the forsterite grain in the centre and a dashed line indicating the orientation of the FIB section. b, A TEM image of the FIB cross section of the forsterite. c, An expanded TEM image from the red outlined area in b, showing the solar wind damage on the rim and SEP tracks (linear features) in the grain.

We used SEM imaging to identify micrometeoroid impact craters on the basis of their circular morphology, raised rims and the presence of vesicular melt deposits lining the crater floors (Fig. 1b). Micrometre-sized impact craters are commonly observed on contact pad particles and on some particles from the bulk sample. On the surface of contact pad particle OREX-452001-0, we observe ~40 microcraters with diameter typically 1–2 μm. In contrast, the largest crater we have identified is in a particle from bulk sample OREX-803109-0 and is ~10 μm in diameter with radial fractures extending outwards (Fig. 6).

a, A SEM image of the particle showing the crater (dark area) and the radial fractures surrounding it (yellow arrows). b, The crater entrance is lined with vesiculated melt. c, The crater as exposed in the FIB trench before extracting a section for TEM analysis. The red box indicates the area shown in d. d, The Fe–Si–S (RGB) composite chemical map of the crater path through matrix material, including a platy pyrrhotite grain (magenta).

We use solar energetic particle tracks and microcrater densities to constrain recent direct exposure at Bennu's surface (less than millimetre depths). At greater depths (upper few metres), we use the production of the radioactive cosmogenic nuclides (hereafter ‘radionuclides') 10Be and 26Al as well as the stable noble gas nuclide 21Ne by exposure to galactic cosmic rays. Whereas cosmogenic noble gases record the total cosmic ray exposure (CRE) history of the samples, radionuclides record the CRE history of the past 5–10 Myr.

Solar energetic particles leave tracks of ionization damage in anhydrous silicate crystals, and their density can be used as a chronometer for exposure in the uppermost millimetres of the regolith18. The SEP track density in the forsterite exposed on OREX-452001-0 (~1.4 × 109 cm−2) is consistent with an exposure age of ~45,000 years (Methods).

Microcrater densities also constrain the surface exposure age of particles. While contact pad particle OREX-452001-0 has the highest microcrater density, this estimate represents a minimum density for this particle because we did not count micrometre-sized pits without melt as microcraters. We use this density to estimate the exposure age by comparison with the cumulative microcrater production rate observed for lunar rocks and soils19, giving a range in exposure age of ~20,000–85,000 years (Methods).

Bennu particles (Methods), such as those returned from Ryugu20, contain abundant primordially trapped noble gas components that mostly overprint the much less abundant cosmogenic noble gases21. Some particles that were exposed at Bennu's surface also contain abundant trapped solar wind, evident in He and Ne. Because the trapped components are so dominant, any resolvable excesses of cosmogenic 21Ne are minimal if present at all. Otherwise, upper limits were determined (see data in ref. 21). Where resolvable, the concentration of cosmogenic 21Ne in the Bennu particles (2.8 and 4.2 × 10−9 cm3 STP g−1, where STP is standard temperature and pressure) suggests a CRE age of 2–7 Myr, depending mostly on the depth where the exposure to galactic cosmic rays occurred.

We measured the concentrations of the cosmogenic radionuclides 10Be (half-life of 1.36 Myr (ref. 22)), 26Al (half-life of 0.705 Myr (ref. 23)) and 36Cl (half-life of 0.301 Myr (ref. 24)) in aggregate sample OREX-803047-0. (Supplementary Table 3). The cosmogenic 10Be and 26Al concentrations correspond to irradiation depths of 170–180 and 100–110 g cm−2, respectively25. Since the collected sample is probably a mixture of materials from the surface and deeper in the crater26, scenarios where individual particles were exposed at different depths and for different durations may explain the cosmogenic nuclide record of the sample. Regardless of the different histories of individual particles, the cosmogenic radionuclide results indicate a minimum CRE age of >3 Myr for the sample, which is consistent with the ages >2 Myr derived from cosmogenic 21Ne here. Nevertheless, some caution is needed as noble gas measurements were performed on different samples than those used for radionuclide measurements.

If the 2–7 Myr CRE age of the samples that we examined is representative of Bennu's average surface, then the exposure time of the top few metres of regolith is less than the asteroid's oldest estimated age (~1 Gyr) by more than two orders of magnitude27. This indicates that the uppermost few metres of Bennu are frequently replenished with material from depths >5–10 m, probably by a combination of impact gardening and downslope mass movements. This is consistent with spacecraft observations indicating a dynamic surface, including particle ejection events (for example, ref. 28), mass movement within the past few hundreds of thousands of years27,29 and a crater size frequency distribution indicating that the upper ~10 m of Bennu is resurfaced on a timescale of 10–65 Myr (ref. 30). Finally, our initial results for Bennu materials indicate a CRE age of approximately 5 million years, similar to the age determined for Ryugu20, suggesting that these two asteroids have experienced comparable surface evolution histories.

With the analysis of samples from Bennu, we can compare weathering timescales from a remote versus laboratory perspective, while also linking spectral characteristics to their microstructural and chemical sources. The younger SEP exposure age we find from a particle collected at the surface (~104 years) suggests that space weathering changes occurred on a more rapid timescale than was estimated from spacecraft data (105 years).

Spacecraft measurements also suggest that surface material on Bennu becomes brighter and bluer with continued exposure to the space environment, in contrast to lunar and ordinary chondritic materials2,3,31. Compositionally, Bennu samples contain hydrated amorphous Mg,Na phosphate1,32; a similar phase in Ryugu samples displays a blue slope across visible wavelengths33, suggesting that such material may be contributing to Bennu and Ryugu reflectance spectra. In laboratory studies with analogue materials, the bluing trend has been attributed to a variety of optically opaque minerals, including carbonaceous materials, sulfides or magnetite6,34. The melt deposits on the surfaces of Bennu particles contain abundant nano-phase and micro-phase inclusions of FeNi metal and FeNi sulfides. Spectral modelling of troilite (FeS) inclusions in silicate hosts indicate that particles >40 nm in diameter cause bluing of reflectance spectra across visible–near-infra-red wavelengths34. This link between nano-phase sulfides, which we observe in the samples, and increasingly blue spectral characteristics offers a fresh paradigm for space weathering on airless carbonaceous bodies where nano- and microscale sulfide inclusions influence the evolution of spectral properties observed through remote sensing, rather than the nano-phase Fe metal. These observations provide context for space weathering processes across the Solar System and may have implications for rocky bodies enriched in sulfur, such as Mercury.

Space weathering is a ubiquitous process affecting airless bodies across the Solar System, and understanding the relative contributions of its constituent processes and their timescales is critical for interpreting the mineralogy and evolution of these planetary surfaces. The canonical model for space weathering constructed from lunar observations suggested that solar wind modifies airless surfaces on short timescales (104–106 years), whereas impacts operate on longer timescales (108–109 years)35,36. This was reinforced by observations from Itokawa samples, where solar wind appeared to be the dominant space weathering agent, acting to alter spectral characteristics more efficiently and on shorter timescales than impacts8,36.

However, we can now compare space weathering characteristics in returned samples across all our asteroidal collections (Itokawa, Ryugu and Bennu). Melt deposits occur in <0.5% of Itokawa samples37, 2% of Ryugu particles16 and 20% of Bennu particles (although analyses of additional material may improve these statistics). In contrast, Ryugu samples have the lowest SEP track density ages (6,000 years), compared with those from Bennu (45,000 years) and Itokawa (50,000 years)8,16. Together, these results suggest that micrometeoroid impacts play a more important role in the space weathering of asteroidal surfaces than was suggested from early observations of asteroidal returned samples.

Comparing space weathering characteristics between only Ryugu and Bennu samples reveals a common suite of products, including vesiculated melts with nano- and micro-phase FeNi sulfide inclusions, solar wind-damaged rims, microcraters and the unusual metal whiskers and nitride layers described above12,13,16,17. This is unsurprising given their mineralogical and compositional similarity and their exposure to the near-Earth space environment. However, the observed SEP track and microcrater densities indicate that Bennu samples have an order-of-magnitude longer surface exposure than Ryugu samples. In addition, there are apparent differences in the spectral slopes, colours and strength of the 2.7-µm hydration feature between Ryugu and Bennu in spacecraft data31.

The spectral slope differences between Ryugu and Bennu31 were attributed to different space weathering trends operating on the bodies, but the asteroids' similar chemical and microstructural characteristics and the age relationship we infer from the samples indicates that the space weathering trend is a single path with spectral slopes evolving from red to blue over time. Ryugu sits at an earlier stage of this pathway, and we predict that it will eventually develop a bluer, Bennu-like spectral slope. Other factors such as particle size, minor mineralogical differences or rock surface textures may also contribute to differences between the asteroids.

The space weathering characteristics of Bennu and Ryugu revealed by remote sensing and sample analysis suggest that space weathering is fundamentally different for primitive carbonaceous bodies compared with the Moon and S-complex asteroids in four ways:

Micrometeoroid impacts are more efficiently driving rapid spectral changes relative to solar wind effects on hydrated carbonaceous asteroids, which also contrasts with existing models for inner Solar System weathering timescales (see, for example, ref. 36).

Observations from Bennu samples have demonstrated that impacts not only alter the surfaces of C-complex asteroids more substantially but do so on a far shorter timescale than hypothesized on the basis of lunar surfaces (104 years compared with >108 years).

The effects of micrometeoroid impacts are known to be magnified by the low mechanical strength38, higher volatile content and more efficient melting of carbonaceous surfaces versus their anhydrous lunar and asteroidal counterparts. These properties result in the wide dispersion of melt ejecta by shocked volatiles39.

Spectral slopes are driven towards bluing with continued exposure, rather than reddening, a reversal of lunar-style space weathering spectral trends. Differences in surface exposure timescales between Ryugu (shorter) and Bennu (longer) support the hypothesis that carbonaceous asteroids experience a pathway of weathering driven by early reddening, followed by eventual bluing2. Bennu and Ryugu are snapshots of asteroids at two different stages of this pathway, with Ryugu exhibiting a redder spectral slope, lower crater density and younger surface exposure ages, and Bennu showing a bluer slope, higher crater densities and longer surface exposure ages. These observations provide another metric by which relative surface ages could be determined for carbonaceous asteroids in the main belt.

Recent crater distribution and retention age analyses40 confirm that rubble-pile asteroids can experience exceptionally rapid regolith mixing and resurfacing, with turnover timescales on Ryugu of 103–105 years. This rapid cycling suppresses long-term spectral bluing and promotes the exposure of fresh material, especially on Ryugu, where younger surface ages result in a redder spectral slope. Bennu, having experienced fewer resurfacing events, has transitioned further along the spectral weathering pathway towards bluer slopes. These processes, driven by impact gardening and surface flows, appear to dominate space weathering on carbonaceous asteroids, fundamentally distinguishing them from those on the Moon and S-type asteroids.

Evidence for space weathering on particle surfaces (for example, vesicular melt deposits with embedded nano-particles) was identified using SEM of particles extracted from contact pad OREX-452000-0 and from aggregate samples OREX-501017-0, OREX-803081-0 and OREX-803164-0 (where ‘aggregate' signifies a sample consisting of unsorted particles). We used a JEOL 7900F scanning electron microscope at NASA Johnson Space Center (JSC) operated in low vacuum mode to image the contact pad particles without a conductive coating. For other aggregate samples, we used a JEOL 7600F field-emission scanning electron microscope also at JSC. To prepare the samples by FIB milling, we used an FEI Quanta3D at JSC and the FEI Helios Nanolab 660 G3 in the University of Arizona's Kuiper-Arizona Laboratory for Astromaterials Analysis (K-ALFAA). TEM analysis of the microstructural and chemical characteristics of space weathering was performed using the JEOL 2500SE TEM at JSC, the aberration-corrected Hitachi HF5000 in K-ALFAA and the aberration-corrected, monochromated Thermo Themis Z at Purdue. Each TEM is equipped with a silicon drift detector for energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy and a Gatan EELS for chemical analyses.

The complete noble gas data set, obtained at ETH Zurich with a custom-built sector-field mass spectrometer (all isotopes of He–Xe), is presented in a companion paper21. The cosmogenic 21Ne concentrations used here were derived by two-component decomposition of the measured Ne composition between the trapped end-member and cosmogenic Ne typical for material of CI chemical composition. Samples were transported to ETH from the NHM London in N2 atmosphere. They were subsequently handled in a N2-filled glove box, weighed using a Mettler Toledo UMX2 ultra-microbalance in hermetically sealed micro-weighing containers and loaded into an infra-red laser cell without any exposure to air. Three particles (OREX-800032-102, OREX-800032-103 and OREX-800032-104) were placed individually into the laser chamber and pumped down to 10−10 mbar. Each particle was melted completely in two steps using a Nd:YAG laser working at 1,064 nm wavelength. Gases released upon exposure to the infra-red laser were purified, cryogenically separated into He–Ne, Ar and Kr–Xe and analysed according to standard procedures41.

We received ~12 mg of an aggregate sample OREX-803014-0 of loose, unsorted material <1 mm in size for analysis of cosmogenic radionuclides by accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS). The sample was split into 5-mm-sized particles and a bulk sample, OREX-803047-0, of 9.85 mg. We dissolved the bulk sample along with Be and Cl carriers in a HF/HNO3 mixture. After dissolution, we separated Cl as AgCl for analysis of cosmogenic 36Cl by AMS. A small aliquot of the dissolved sample was split for chemical analysis by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry. The chemical composition of the sample (Supplementary Table 3) is consistent with that of a similar aggregate sample, OREX-803015-0, measured previously by others1. We then added 1.5 mg of Al carrier and separated Be and Al from the remaining solution for analysis of cosmogenic 10Be and 26Al by AMS. The AMS measurements of the 10Be/Be, 26Al/Al and 36Cl/Cl ratios were performed at the Purdue Rare Isotope Measurement Laboratory42. The measured ratios were normalized to those of well-known AMS standards22,23,24. From the normalized ratios, the amount of Be, Al and Cl carrier, and the sample mass, we calculated the 10Be, 26Al and 36Cl concentrations of the sample. Concentrations (in atoms per gram) wre then converted to disintegrations per minute per kg and are reported in Supplementary Table 3. The measured concentrations of 10Be and 26Al are compared with production rates for 2π irradiation from model calculations25, adopting the bulk composition of Bennu aggregate samples1. If the measured concentrations represent saturation values during steady-state exposure conditions, they provide a direct measure of the irradiation depth of the sample.

We determined a SEP track exposure age from the track measurements in OREX-452001-0 by using the 1 AU track production rate calibration from ref. 18 and an r−1.7 model43 for the heliocentric decay of the SEP flux to account for the parts of Bennu's elliptical orbit beyond 1 AU, where r is the heliocentric radius. The measurements were made on a FIB section prepared using the JSC FIB and images obtained using the JEOL 2500SE STEM at JSC.

The microcrater exposure age for OREX-4520001-0 was determined by measuring the number of definite craters in the measured area (~40 craters in 0.6 mm2 of surface area) and using the crater production rates from ref. 19 of ~0.3 craters per square centimetre per year for 2-μm-diameter craters and 0.08 craters per square centimetre per year for 1-μm craters (for a 2π exposure), giving exposure ages ranging between ~20,000 and 85,000 years. However, this estimate represents the minimum crater density for this particle because we did not count micrometre-sized pits or other circular features without melt as microcraters.

Title: At This Point, It's Impossible to Know What the Trump Phone Looks Like
Description:
It's been over two months since Trump Mobile announced the T1 Phone was being “Made in the USA” designed “with American values in mind,” and it seems that anyone deciding to preorder it still can't be sure exactly what phone they might receive.

In posts on X and Instagram on Wednesday, the Trump Mobile account encouraged followers to place their preorder, promising them that “the wait is almost over.” This was joined by an image that looks nothing like the one of the T1 phone that's currently on the Trump Mobile website. It instead looks rather suspiciously like the rear side of a Samsung Galaxy S25.

Not just that, it actually appears to be the back of a third-party S25 phone case from Spigen that has been photoshopped gold and stamped with the T1 logo and trademark American flag. Still visible, just behind the flag, is the Spigen company logo.

Spigen's social media account commented under the post on X with an apt “??? bro what” before writing on its own page that it had a “lawsuit incoming.” WIRED has reached out to Spigen for comment.

This isn't the first time questions have been raised about what the T1 Phone will actually turn out to be. Not long after it was announced in June, the specs of the phone changed on the Trump Mobile website, and claims that it would be made in the USA were deleted.

Currently, the Trump Mobile website claims the T1 Phone will have a 6.2-inch punch-hole AMOLED screen with 120-Hz refresh rate, 50-MP main camera with a 16-MP selfie camera, and a 5,000-mAh battery. There's also 256 GB of internal storage, an in-screen fingerprint sensor, and “AI face unlock.”

It's priced at $499, which includes a $100 deposit that apparently covers shipping and handling as well as your first month of Trump Mobile service. This suggests buyers will be required to use Trump Mobile with their T1 Phone, with no clear details before you authorize payment of any ongoing commitment to the service.

Users can, at least, wait to receive the phone before activating the service and can request a full refund “at any time prior to the shipment of the phone.”

As to what the phone will look like when (and if) that ever happens, it's impossible to know—and Trump Mobile seems as unsure as the rest of us. All of which isn't helping to curb suspicions that, right now, the T1 Phone—initially pegged to arrive in August—probably doesn't exist in any shape or form.
